awd_titl_txt: Conference on Harmonic Analysis and Fractal Sets
awd_abstract_narration:
The award supports a March 2023 conference at the Ohio State University (Columbus campus) on the topics of harmonic analysis and fractal geometry.  Fractals are geometric objects which are highly irregular, exhibiting detail at arbitrarily small scales.  Such sets arise naturally in mathematics, and have applications to a diverse array of problems in science and engineering.  Harmonic analysis emerged in the late 20th century as a tool for the study of the geometry of fractal sets, and in return fractal geometry has motivated many interesting questions in harmonic analysis. This event brings together researchers to find new synergies between existing methods and to formulate new approaches to build on recent progress at the intersection of these fields.

The focus of the conference is on geometric properties of fractal sets using tools from harmonic analysis. A classical problem in this area is the Falconer distance problem, which asks how large the Hausdorff dimension of a compact set must be to ensure that it determines a positive Lebesgue measure set of pairwise distances.  More generally, one may inquire when high dimensional sets determine more complicated patterns, leading to a host of fascinating questions about finite point configurations.  These problems can be studied via bounds for convolution operators, bringing to bear tools from harmonic analysis. Another classical example is the Kakeya problem, which asks when sets containing a line segment in every direction must have full Hausdorff dimension. The Kakeya problem, in turn, is closely tied to Fourier restriction theory. A recurring theme throughout the conference is the relationship between the Fourier transform and notions of structure such as Hausdorff dimension.

https://u.osu.edu/hafs2023/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In recent years, major advances have occured in the intersection of harmonic analysis and fractal geometry.  We organized a weekend conference entitled HAFS2023: Harmonic Analysis and Fractal Sets at Ohio State University in March 2023 which brought together experts whose research focused on questions related to the geometry of fractal sets.

Fractal sets provide realistic models for many natural phenomena, and understanding the geometry of fractals has served researchers in a wide range of sciences. In physics, applications of fractals include describing Brownian motion of particles, turbulence in fluids, and fractal percolation. In biology and medicine, fractal geometry has been applied to describe the vascularity of tumors and to study MRI diffusion data. Our conference brought together researchers with the aim of advancing the understanding of these complicated sets on which engineers, medical researchers, and physicists rely.

The conference was one of the few recent major meetings on harmonic analysis and fractal sets that is held in the midwest. HAFS was designed to engage and encourage students and junior scientists early in their careers, help build a community of researchers, reveal new directions for research, and create novel links between harmonic analysis and the geometry of fractals. Encouraging participation of young researchers as well as under-represented minorities was a high priority for the meeting, and we provided funding for over 40 junior mathematicians to attend the event.  The conference offered a unique experience to the participants and provided them with a combination of opportunities, including attending lectures by leading mathematicians in a range of fields between harmonic analysis, fractals and geometric measure theory and disseminating their own mathematical results. 


Last Modified: 03/01/2024
Modified by: Alexander K Mcdonald
